g.text: here is considerable uncertainty in model projections of
rst century precipitation changes over California
. These uncertainties are largely a consequence of the
sensitivity of Californian rainfall to both tropical and mid-latitude
atmospheric circulation changes, such as variability in the El
Niño/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) and shifts in the Paci
s winter precipitation has decreased over the
past two decades, and between 2012 and 2016 California has
entered into one of the most severe droughts on record
impacts of reduced rainfall have been intensi
high temperatures that have enhanced potential evapotranspira-
anthropogenic component arising from increased temperatures,
with the likelihood of such warming-enhanced droughts expected
The exceptionally dry conditions during the winters of
2015 were accompanied by a prominent dynamical feature:
a persistent geopotential ridge located in the North Paci
ridge pushed storm tracks further north, resulting in wetter than
normal conditions over the northwest and substantial drying over
the southwest of the United States
and anomalously warm sea-surface temperatures (SST) over the
c in 2012/13 and 2013/14 may have helped
simulations forced with observed SSTs alone were unable to
capture all the important features of the recent precipitation
may in part be attributable to other factors, such as internal
A positive geopotential anomaly in the North Paci
to the recent drought. Similar anomalies are known to be associated
with precipitation decline across the American southwest
of the existing literature points to anomalous tropical SSTs and
convection as dynamical drivers of the geopotential changes in the
. However, at least one study has implicated
Arctic sea-ice loss as a possible cause of the drier winters over the
involves surface warming and geopotential height increase over the
newly open ocean areas in the Arctic, which in turn drives anom-
alous ridging over the North Paci
. Although this mechanism is not con-
sidered to be a primary driver of California
the pronounced Arctic sea-ice loss over the satellite era and the
dramatic sea-ice retreat expected by the end of the twenty-
. Motivated by this, we focus on elucidating the possible
mechanisms by which large-scale sea-ice cover changes could affect
A novel feature of our approach is that we sample the uncer-
tainties in selected sea-ice physics parameters (see
), thereby obtaining an ensemble of simulations
These are compared to control simulations representative of sea-
ice conditions at the end of the twentieth century. A comparison
and control simulations allows us to
isolate the atmospheric response that is solely associated with
changes in sea-ice cover. Neither the SSTs nor the sea-ice cover
are prescribed in our model simulations. We are therefore able to
changes necessary for propagation of high-to-low latitude atmo-
parameter perturbations allow for energy budget conservation.
Our primary interest is in the fast atmospheric response to
rst decades after the sea-ice loss has
occurred. This fast response is mediated by the surface ocean, and
typically dominates the overall response during the
or decades after the initial high-latitude perturbation
Impact of sea-ice physics parameter perturbations on Arctic and Antarctic sea-ice cover.
ice concentrations, March. Shown are monthly mean sea-ice concentrations. Areas contained within contour lines have sea-ice fractions larger than 15%.
Thick black lines denote control ensemble means, thick purple lines show
) simulations. The colored shading indicates the average observed September (
2001 (from the Center for Satellite Exploitation and Research; http://nsidc.org/data/sipn/data-sets.
html#seaice-conc-ext). A brief comparison of Arctic vs. Antarctic sea-ice changes is provided in Supplementary Note 1
